question_list.author: Celia Warren
question_list.text:
Oh, don't throw your toys out your pram!
Yes, I treat all your emails as spam.
Hurt your feelings? Don't care;
I don't like you, so there!
Just accept that I don't give a damn!
question_list.question: Why do I treat all your emails as spam?
alternate_answers:
Because I don't like you, so there!
Your feelings? I don't really care.
Just accept that I'm cold,
And your messages, old,
Are as welcome as a grizzly bear.

question_list.author: MikeAq
question_list.text:
Mr. Thistle, what's this all about?
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!
question_list.question: Does Mr. Thistle follow our rules?
alternate_answers: Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules consistently. He often disregards them without explanation or justification.

Based on the limericks provided, the question appears to be about the limerick that mentions "Mr. Thistle". The relevant limerick is:

"Mr. Thistle, what's this all about? 
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!"

This limerick suggests that Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules, as the speaker is blowing the whistle on him for dismissing and flouting the rules.

question_list.author: MikeAq
question_list.text:
To compose a morose epicedium
Can brighten one's torpor and tedium.
I myself have an urge
To create a sad dirge —
One not overly mournful, just medium.
question_list.question: How can one brighten one's torpor and tedium?
alternate_answers:
The limerick suggests that composing a morose epicedium (a funeral song or poem) can help brighten one's torpor and tedium. The limerick states:

"To compose a morose epicedium 
Can brighten one's torpor and tedium.
I myself have an urge
To create a sad dirge —
One not overly mournful, just medium."

So the answer is that writing a moderately melancholy funeral poem or song can help alleviate boredom and listlessness, according to the limerick.

Compose a morose epicedium.
Craft a sad dirge, not too mournful,
Just medium, not scornful,
To lift your spirits, a musical medium.

question_list.author: SheilaB
question_list.text:
Uncle Wayne always gives me a pain.
His ideas are vain and inane.
He's both asinine (fatuous)
And a gas bag who's flatuous.
I treat the old fool with disdain.
question_list.question: What is wrong with Uncle Wayne's ideas?
question_list.answer: Uncle Wayne's ideas are vain and inane.
alternate_answers:
Uncle Wayne's ideas are considered vain and inane,
He's both asinine and flatuous, causing disdain.

Based on the limerick, there are a few things wrong with Uncle Wayne's ideas:

1. They are described as "vain and inane" - meaning they are empty, worthless, and foolish.

2. He is characterized as being "asinine" - which means stupid or foolish. 

3. He is also described as being a "gas bag" who is "flatuous" - implying his ideas are full of hot air and empty rhetoric.

4. The narrator treats Uncle Wayne with "disdain" - showing a strong dislike and lack of respect for his ideas.

Overall, the limerick portrays Uncle Wayne's ideas as being foolish, stupid, and unworthy of serious consideration. The narrator clearly has a very negative view of his uncle's thought processes and opinions.

question_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
question_list.text:
That damn call button jockey, room 9,
Is a pain in the base of my spine.
For no reason he rings
About minuscule things.
His sole purpose? To hear himself whine.
question_list.question: What is the sole purpose of the occupant of room 9?
alternate_answers: The sole purpose of the occupant of room 9 is to repeatedly press the call button, which can be quite frustrating for others.
The sole purpose of the occupant of room 9 is to ring the call button for no significant reason, mainly to hear himself whine.

limerick_list.author: AronKuppersmith
limerick_list.text:
The lead batter's pop fly soared to right.
Though the outfielder kept it in sight,
A low cloud sailed away
And he errored that play
'Cause, like Bruce, he was blinded by light.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Epistemologists study the gist
Of the limits of knowledge. They list
What we can and can't know
About knowing. Their row
Is a tough one to hoe. (They're so 'pist'.)

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
At the disco, 'neath circling light
We danced and we boogied each night.
I remember the scene
Just this past Halloween —
We were dressed up as boogeymen, right?

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
Of Twinkies and Ho Hos I dream.
That Oreo "stuff" I esteem.
I highly regard
Whipped sugar and lard,
That cream-less cream filling called  creme.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
"The macaroni-named beast?  He is no fuss!
He can sit on the floor or the sofas."
So the fat penguin sat,
With a crest (but no hat)
In our flat — Eudyptes chrysolophus.

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
The belga, alas, is no more:
Worth (in Belgian francs) one more than four,
Used in foreign exchange,
With a life of short range,
For its years were one less than a score.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My memory losses you're linking
To alcohol? That's what you're thinking?
As a very young pup,
Doc, I'd often throw up,
But I've never blacked out from my drinking.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
Caveman Dana had many a son,
And some daughters, at least twenty-one!
Did his deities bless
Him with fruitfulness? Yes!
He did multiplication for fun.

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
It was weird at the monsters' big bash;
As they danced, there was heard a big crash.
Wolfie jostled Drac's bride,
And then fangs pierced his hide.
Neither bashful, they bashed at the Mash!

limerick_list.author: mino
limerick_list.text:
That African plant called the aloe
Is a useful and succulent fellow.
	On a burn, it'll soothe;
	But a taste (though quite smooth)
Makes you bolt for the loo with a bellow.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Here's a limerick on the word blah—
Some will say that it goes a bit far.
It has no definition
But OEDILFian permission
To give you some fun—ha ha ha!

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
My car has some customization,
Some top of the line fabrication.
I have added some stripes,
High-end wheels, shiny pipes.
It's more hobby than mere transportation.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
From the library, Violet took
A large tome: The World Travelers' Book,
Not to read but dip into,
See the places she's been to,
So in one or two chapters she'll look.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Channel bass is a fish that's delicious!
It's healthy, low fat, and nutritious.
It's size just astounds—
It can weigh ninety pounds,
But be careful! Those fins can be vicious!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Though this writer's ostensible topic
Is creatures, his stories Aesopic
(On tortoises, sables,
And foxes) are fables
Whose morals are plainly anthropic.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
A butcher among Roman lords,
Gnaeus Pompey killed Marian hordes.
Sulla called him The Great
For "defending" the state
With "Your laws can't stand up to our swords!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
There's a place in my heart that I keep
For the sea creatures dreamed of in sleep.
I feel very empathic
Toward beasts eurybathic,
Who survive where it's shallow or deep.

limerick_list.author: Jean McEwen
limerick_list.text:
You can't just interchange "is" and "are."
Such stretching of rules goes too far.
Delimitation I'll place
On your right to debase
English grammar.  Don't lower the bar!

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
When Herr Hitler took over as head
Of the Reich, he quit painting and said,
"I'm now Chancellor, so,
To my chancellery go,
Tear down pictures; pin maps there instead!"

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
Convenience, a much cherished trait,
Has become more important of late.
Handy setups I find
Save my steps and my mind,
Now that age is impeding my gait.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A bear jam, a new term for most,
Will occur when a tourist, engrossed
By a Yellowstone bear,
Slows his car down to stare.
(It's not something for spreading on toast.)

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
A black hole singularity? Well,
It's a thing few can know or can tell.
But Belinskii, Khalatnikov,
Lifshitz, a hat-trick of
Physicists, can: BKL!

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I had a strong bent (inclination)
Toward changing my orientation.
With the straight life cut loose,
I'm now bent (other use
Meaning "gay").  Guys are now my fixation.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
Know that greenhorn who's new to the ranch?
He will do things that sure make me blanch.
The kid once turned his butt
To a bull during rut.
I found him draped over a branch!

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
You're attending a college that's out
For some profit? It seems there's some doubt:
You may not for your pain
Get a job, even gain
A degree to be framed or to tout.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
Breaking news: when a story's emerging.
Breaking cover: from trenches we're surging.
Breaking down: when you cry
(Breaking up might be why).
Breaking wind: excess gases you're purging.

limerick_list.author: Reia Light
limerick_list.text:
"I'm so happy! It's been the best day!"
Paul exclaimed. "Yes, I'm totally gay!"
"That could be misconstrued,"
Snickered Ron, "but 'sup, dude?"
And Paul grinned. "I got lucky with Ray!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A musician can't make playing pay
If he's shooting up drugs every day.
Dirty habits will eat
Into profits tout de suite.
He's just throwing his money away.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I've invented the best-tasting candy bar —
And its size is just right! What a dandy bar!
It's a no-flour sweet
In a hand-shape that's neat
And compact, so I call it a "HandiBar".

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Dottie claims my opinions are rot.
When I say something's good, she says "Not!"
When I cheer, Dottie boos;
My reviews she pooh-poohs,
And she downplays what judgment I've got.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
I stopped shaving, and just as I feared,
A profusion of whiskers appeared.
It looks so out of place
On my baby-like face,
Such a wooly (or flocculent) beard!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Danish Dynamite"? No! That's none other
Than an overseas football team, Mother!
You're so wrong! It's, by God,
The Danes' national squad.
Ain't no way it's Napoleon's brother!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
With old age I've become presbyopic.
In your records, the print's microscopic,
But it says, in your case,
That your gland's out of place.
Your adrenal, my dear, is dystopic.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Acœlomates don't have a cavity
To cushion their innards from gravity.
So for fear they might fall
They don't grow very tall,
Nor indulge in excessive depravity.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
There once was a self-searching Pole
Who discovered a hole in his soul,
But his hopes were not sunk—
He became a Zen monk,
And he filled it with one empty bowl.

limerick_list.author: Nitelaf
limerick_list.text:
I've been touring through Europe this year,
Doing serious research... on beer!
I've tried hundreds while here;
What's my favorite? It's clear:
"To heaven and bock" is my cheer!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
If you prize the old Japanese mode,
And you won't let its values erode,
And rank honor above
Faith in life or in love,
Follow Bushido (samurai code).

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I'm a Cancer, which serves to connote
I'll be crabby with you if you gloat
After butting my head.
You're a Capricorn, said
To enjoy getting everyone's goat.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My wife has been named in a plot
To sell 200 kilos of pot.
"I thought you above
Such behavior, my love."
But she answered, "Apparently not."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Cost-effectiveness means when you weigh
What you spend (that's the price that you pay)
Against all that you earn,
You might finally learn
You have money to burn—and can play.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
At the nightclub, this guy's over-tipping,
Most of all, when a dancer is stripping.
Hey, he lives on a pension!
How's it done? I should mention:
That he still has his job—double dipping.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Great-granny might think it quite strange
Not having to blacklead a range.
If you readily tire
Of lighting a fire,
A cooker's a welcome exchange.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
The facets you've ground can collapse
At the smallest of innocent taps.
A cabochon's assets?
The gem has no facets —
Or an infinite number, perhaps.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I'm edacious, just can't get enough
Of the things that I want—y'know, stuff.
Sure, my greed is a curse,
But my neighbors are worse.
(Keeping up with the jonesing is tough.)

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Want a beefburger—nice, sorta rare?
Eh, what's that that you say—you don't dare?
What's E. coli? Nah, don't
Be afraid—a bite won't
Do you harm. And what's that—mad cow scare?

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
To actuate means "put in motion,"
Like starting this verse (I've a notion)
And pushing it on
'Til it's weary and wan
And is happy to drown in the ocean.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Engineers get a good education
In science. They use calculation
Based on theory, but know
That good guessing might show
Fine results: they must use estimation.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"You've expressed your desirousness clearly.
I know that you long for me dearly,"
She said, "but my gripe
Is you're just not my type —
And I mean that sincerely — not nearly."

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
The calliope's value is moot;
It plays music resembling a hoot.
When it toots like a whistle
The noise makes me bristle —
Vocal beauty is not its long suit.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Why rhymy Y rhythms? Why try?
My syzygy's spry, by my cry.
Y's glyphs ply my syth,
Scry myrrhy-sylph myth —
Shy sky nymphs fly spryly, by Y!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
With a hammer, the woman bucks ore
On an anvil—a nine-to-five chore.
After screening out bits
To re-crush them, she quits
For the day, but tomorrow there's more.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
An analphabet knocked at my door
Seeking tutelage—hard to ignore.
Every day she returned,
And in no time she'd learned
How to read—now it's books by the score.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Mix its petals with yeast, and proceed,
Brewing all of the wine that you need
From these bright yellow blooms,
While your gardener assumes
That the dandelion's merely a weed.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
To define arctic wolf? Piece o' cake:
White-furred beast that won't keep you awake
If you live where it's hot.
It's decidedly not
Just some eskimo dude on the make.

limerick_list.author: stella
limerick_list.text:
On my gran's brand new laptop Toshiba
I loaded the music of Biber:
"These trumpet sonatas
Should do you for starters."
Cried Grandma, "Ah, Biber! Arriba!"

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
I'm incensed and I'm bent out of shape!
When you filmed us, you promised that tape
Was for you, not the Net!
Please—I want to forget,
But my fans will not let me escape.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The gluepot is desperately wanting
The condom to give up his chaunting
("I'm rubber; you're glue").
But, alas, since it's true,
He's resigned to the teasing and taunting.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
First some flour and egg whites you take.
Add some sugar, stir briskly, and bake.
Then allow it to cool.
It'll cause you to drool,
This dessert known as angel food cake.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
With authoritativeness, Trump said, "I'm speaking:
It's official — go plug all the leaking!"
From the staff, a bold speaker
Said, "Sir, you're prime leaker!"
She was fired in a Trump fit-of-pique-ing.

limerick_list.author: Fifine
limerick_list.text:
Celtic Tiger: growth rapidly spread.
Then the Irish economy bled.
Now the wolf's at the door,
And the tiger's no more:
It's the sick man of Europe instead.

limerick_list.author: Kalleh
limerick_list.text:
I always take blankie with me,
While sleeping or climbing a tree.
My mom calls it "schmatte" —
A rag with a lotta
Worn edges and tatters, you see.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Sue's abusing the fruits that I brought her.
She's plunged them in boiling hot water!
Now she's moved them to ice—
Tortured twice in a trice!
Says it's blanching. That's nothing I taught her.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
His paintings in Florence are shown,
But Giovanni Cimabue is known
For winning fame's lotto
As teacher of Giotto —
Not so much for work done on his own.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Their testosterone levels are low,
So the hair on their faces won't grow.
These eunuchoid creatures
Have feminine features.
They're males but their maleness won't show.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I'm afraid of my shadow; I hold
Onto worry and fear, and I fold.
Even harmless events
Make me nervous and tense.
It's a good thing my shadow is bold.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Gippy tummy is giving you pain?
Diarrhoea — you've got it again?
Bananas with rice,
Salt and honey's a nice
Way to ease it. A balm for your bane.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
Help Wanted: Young man with degree
To serve as a delegatee.
Please know not to ask
Why each mind-numbing task
Must be handled by you and not me.

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
Blaydon's home to a mischievous spirit
Who plays brownie-like tricks on those near it.
If you feign you don't care
That the boggart is there—
It bedevils your home 'til you fear it.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
"You thinking what I'm thinking, lovey?"
"I'm thinking I'd love to, my dovey,
Except that I'm freezing!
Before we start squeezing,
Replenish the stove with some Bovey!"

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
If beauty is only skin deep,
And fashion is following sheep,
Then I have a thesis
That really cosmesis
Should not command prices so steep.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
I have found something new to be mad about,
And what's more I am feeling quite sad about
Being called an odd geezer
By my wife. How to please her?
She claims I'm a cranky old gadabout.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
In my hunger to make a few bucks,
I am hampered, and here is the crux:
It rises, then sinks,
Smells sweetly, then stinks —
The market is always in flux.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
It's Chile, and sometimes it's hot,
But the sere Atacama is not
A good place to grow grain,
'Cause it's not going to rain
In this high-and-dry Andean spot.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I yelled at my horse, "Giddyap!"
My horse yelled right back, "Cut the crap!
Ya knows damn well, master,
I cain't go no faster!
Tell the truth (yaaawn), I could use a nap."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
What a slippery trip it can be
When butterfish swims in the sea.
With his coating of mucus,
He slides through the fucus.
(This food fish just isn't for me.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Alexander II would wail,
"I have never observed it to fail!
Just because our damn name
And our number's the same,
We forever get each other's mail!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
His lament gave us all quite a jolt:
"I'm a moron, a fool; I'm a dolt!
Asked my teacher, 'Lahore
Was involved in what war?'
I replied, 'In the Call Girl Revolt.'"

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
For an adatis, cotton is grown
In India; then, when it's sewn,
It's transported afar
To where cloth-buyers are
And where such cultivation's unknown.

limerick_list.author: Kalleh
limerick_list.text:
The Brits might use bitty for small,
Describing an elf who's not tall,
Vermouth for martinis,
Or itsy bikinis.
(Don't call your man bitty at all!)

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Here's a coupon worth fifty cents off
On the syrup you buy for your cough.
When you fight nasal flow,
Using coupons saves dough,
Which is nothing at which you should scoff.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
"When transcription occurs," said the Dean,
"The DNA's spliced, as we've seen;
Now, with introns removed,
It is easily proved
That the exons remain in the gene."

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
Worried Wes, "This recession ain't funny,
And I frequently fret about money."
But his great-grandma Gertie
Recalled 1930
And told him, "Just deal with it, Sonny."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
My new job's at a radio station.
I forgot its identification —
The call letters.  Groaned
My stern boss when I phoned,
"I am texting you that information."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
At the rail, my habitual space,
I'm methodically doping each race.
That surprise Belmont victor—
The long shot? I picked her,
But had her to place… just in case.

limerick_list.author: GeneralE
limerick_list.text:
Before filming each day I would slog
Across dim foggy moors, through a bog.
Sherlock Holmes was the part
I took deepest to heart,
Like a Rathbone in search of a dog.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Her enduringness all highly praise,
Though her patience, she knows, rarely pays.
Her sly spouse lies and cheats,
Then repeats those deceits.
Her forbearance? A coat that ne'er frays.

limerick_list.author: Rudi
limerick_list.text:
"No dogs in this house!" That's our "Hound Rule."
It's a bylaw—a strict one—a ground rule.
And there's more: in this house,
You should be like a mouse—
That is, quiet. Don't mess with our "Sound Rule."

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
Pascal's mortal foe, a great rascal,
Declared, "My life's pinnacle task'll
Be to kill you (a crime),
In two Passovers' time."
Cried Blaise in amazement, "Dipaschal?"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Gross-out humor elicits disgust
In most people who view it.  It's just
So repulsive.  My son
And his friends find it fun.
For the films geared toward them, it's a must.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
Said a champion spitter from Troon,
"Prepare for astonishment soon!
Just nine, I expect,
Or eight — they'll be checked —
Gobs of mucus will fill that spittoon!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Boblo Island Amusement Park filled
Me with joy in my youth.  How I thrilled
To the Sky Streak and Screamer!
We'd get there by steamer.
No longer.  The crowds have been stilled.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
My onerous daily corvée
Is a source of unease and dismay.
In addition to eating
And bathing, I'm beating
My brains out on limericks all day.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
You'll be glad you rang stores and persisted
In your search for old records resisted
As a kid short of cash.
They're available—dash!
Your sweet echoes of youth are back-listed.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
Your teasing this bear is quite dareful,
But you should be cautious and careful.
He's hungry and glaring,
So stop with the daring!
You'll just end up making the bear full.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The Eagles were one of the best-
selling bands of all time.  They were blessed
By a songwriting pair
With a knack and a flair
For soft rock.  Not to mention the rest.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
With our EEG running, we stroked
The anesthetized cat, then we poked,
While the probes in its brain
Measured, time and again,
The electric potential evoked.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Fall out!" — leave the barracks and then,
In formation with other like men
And women, we'll stand
Till we hear this command:
"Fall out!" (Hit the barracks again.)

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
We begin with a salad that's tossed
And hors d'oeuvres, without care for the cost.
Then we order the fish,
A delectable dish:
It's a sole that's ambrosially sauced.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
I'm growing increasingly wary
Of dating the girl at the dairy.
She has dairymaid skills
That the milking instills,
Like a grip that feels udderly scary.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
My bird, who hawks housewares in York,
Is so chicken, afraid of the stork,
That she'll bill, coo, and spoon
For the whole afternoon,
But duck out when I'm ready to fork.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A pirate who's skillful can drub,
With his club, any guy in the pub,
Then induce the battalions
That guard Spanish galleons
To welcome him into their club.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
In our thumb wars, your thumb won't be found,
And at arm wrestling, I'm more renowned.
But don't stare at me, please—
I'll blink first, ill at ease—
Staring contests I lose, every round.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The boxer went down, but he hopped
To his feet.  One more punch, and he dropped
To the canvas again.
With the ref's count to ten
Proving fruitless, the bout was then stopped.

limerick_list.author: stella
limerick_list.text:
Augustus De Morgan, logician,
Musician and mathematician,
Is known for his laws
Using ands, nots and ors,
And the algebra-logic transition.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
Poor old Sam has some medical trials:
Now it's haemorrhoids stealing his smiles,
As a pain in the arse
Feels like splinters of glass—
Swollen veins are compiled as piles.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Catecholaminergic reactions
Can sometimes be more than distractions.
Epinephrine can start
Overtaxing the heart,
Leading docs to be sued for infractions.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
No, I have no agenbite (remorse)
For goosing bad Goosie, your horse.
She had goosed me twice first.
I, the first time, just cursed;
But "what's good for the gander, of course…"

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
Cocarcinogens acting alone
Won't cause cancer, the studies have shown.
But they'll aid and abet
Your shampoo, cigarette,
Diet soda and cellular phone.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
To compensate parents,  I'd leave,
As repayment for joys that they weave,
A brief time for reflection
And sharing affection—
Just a space for deep breaths, Christmas Eve.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Andy's planning a grand dramaturgical
Portrayal of quandaries surgical.
In his play there's a cheat
In the surgical suite,
As his viewers enjoy the panurgical.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
After riders traverse purple sage,
From that silver-leaved book, take a page:
When you notice new blooms
Then a thunderstorm looms.
Let barometer bush be your gauge.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
With a cushingoid patient the hitch
Is remembering which type is which.
Syndrome's suprarenal
(The same as adrenal);
Disease—a pituitary glitch.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
There is nothing at all, friend, amiss
When some couples make babies like this:
Touch cloacas together.
Yes, birds of a feather
Choose a speedy, cloaca (squirt!) kiss.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
"'Til death do us part," said his Miss.
Then they finished their vows with a kiss.
"Now, my dear, come along.
Walk like this; that way's wrong!"
'Twas his intro to marital bliss.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Call me Doctoress? That would sound weird.
It's an old-fashioned term, as I feared.
I'm a female, you see,
With an M.D. degree.
Call me Doctor, although I've no beard.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
On the surface a model of fineness,
He seems holy, and blessed with divineness;
But he's evil inside,
So it can't be denied
His dark doings give rise to condignness.

limerick_list.author: art bates
limerick_list.text:
My friend's casual approach seems to spring
From his carelessness, often to bring
Him considerable grief
With no end or relief:
Yes, of recklessness, he is the king.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It resembles a palm tree at times
And will flourish in tropical climes
(Not Alaskan or Iowan).
I speak of the dioon.
Its name, sad to say, has few rhymes.

limerick_list.author: man from tashkent
limerick_list.text:
Avant-garde, avant-jazz, avant-mime,
Means the thing is ahead of its time.
  But these verses I write
  Are so nifty, they might
Be considered to be avant-rhyme.

limerick_list.author: Steve Andersen
limerick_list.text:
An atmometer measures capacity
Of evaporative efficacity,
Or power for drying.
Don't tell me I'm lying;
I demand you accept my veracity.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Abstentionism: That is when nations
Keep far from those foreign relations
Where they fear that they might
Risk a loss in a fight,
Making "our needs come first" affirmations.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Hire a clarence cab — seating for four —
To convey us all right to their door.
We'll want something enclosed,
As my wife's indisposed
And the views on the way are a bore!

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
Da Vinci, that wonderful fella,
Couldn't always produce a top sella.
As a genius, he's hailed,
Yet he frequently failed—
Ever try his spaghetti umbrella?

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Blasted starward toward Alpha Centauri,
Maury dreamed of his astronaut glory.
But deep space took its toll
And he hit a black hole —
There's no glory, no story, no Maury.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
This house was a going concern:
Many dollars my brothel would earn.
For these ladies I cared,
So all profits I shared
And their turnover doubled, in turn.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
My gasoline buggy, the source
Of my pride, will be setting the course
For the future.  You'll like
Your own motorized trike
And not dealing with smells from a horse.

limerick_list.author: OxfordVictor
limerick_list.text:
Chef is constantly making mistakes
And invariably burning the cakes.
Since all of his erring
Is always recurring,
I don't think he's got what it takes.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
On movies, where scripts have FX,
It indicates special effects:
For example, a death-ray;
Or CGI breath, say.
Doug Trumbull's were better than sex.

limerick_list.author: John Ramos
limerick_list.text:
I've got pinworms, and that's why I'm bitching;
I find them not one bit enriching.
They live in my gut
And emerge from my butt—
Enterobius means anal itching.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
"Boy, you must get some sleep!" Poppa pled.
Pondered Junior, "That's easier said —
Who can sleep when such foul
Monstrosities growl
Disturbingly under the bed?"

limerick_list.author: Ritepath
limerick_list.text:
"Have eggs and beef liver!" I rave.
"They have choline, my chemical fave.
Acetic acid and it
Form a bond to transmit
The neuronal sensations I crave!"

limerick_list.author: Bit
limerick_list.text:
We thought water was not to be found,
But a spring bubbled up from the ground.
Though we're quenched from its flow,
We're reluctant to go
And forsake its calm, babbling sound.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
I need bittersweet chocolate today;
Nothing else will my sweet tooth allay.
Low in sugar, some cocoa,
My taste buds go loco —
Don't care what the scale says I weigh.

limerick_list.author: David Schildkret
limerick_list.text:
My boogying's awkward at best,
So if you want to dance, be my guest.
For when I hit the floor,
People head for the door
Or at least suggest, "Give it a rest."

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
Anton Chekhov's narration Rule One:
On the fireplace there is a gun
At the start of the tale —
You must write (without fail)
That it shoots before all's said and done.

limerick_list.author: David Schildkret
limerick_list.text:
You do not want this fight to begin;
I suggest it is time to give in.
I will end this debate
With my height and my weight:
I am bigger than you, so I win.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles and OldFitzer
limerick_list.text:
I'm a party with liberal views,
So it's liberal parties I choose.
Yet I might disagree
When some nude debauchee
Throws a libertine party, with booze.

limerick_list.author: Recumbentman
limerick_list.text:
In Georgia, you're certain to find
Things to cherish and folks who are kind.
Through my sorrow and pain
It will always remain,
Like a good old sweet song, on my mind.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Ecclesiastes — its view of humanity
Puts it thus: "All is vanity, vanity!"
It is deep and devout,
But some are in doubt,
Saying, "Can this be true Christianity?"

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
When a buxom young bookseller hocks
All the books in her bookselling stocks,
Then the bookselling sucks—
Making buckets of bucks
Isn't done selling books by the box.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Dem contenders did vie: twenty-four.
That's two dozen— but wait, there's one more!
Some did not make the stage.
How did viewers all gauge
Which debater was best? Who kept score?

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Accombination is thusly defined:
"A combining." But what is combined?
Maybe eggs, milk, and flour,
Or white and black power,
Or the efforts of body and mind.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
That empiric (unqualified hack
With no obvious curative knack)
On the hospital's roster
Is just an imposter
Whose license needs lifting, that quack.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
When you're using acrylic to paint
(It's plastic-based, oil-based it ain't),
It's easy to clean—
Water-soluble, keen—
Quick to dry, it makes oil paint quite quaint.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
A chicken once asked herself, "Why
Am I crossing the road? I could die
Without ever knowing
Wherefore I am going
To get to the other road si—"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I was holding my granddaughter Anne
When: "The babe's had an accident, Fran."
"You say 'accident,' Vince?
That's appropriate, since
That's exactly how Annie began!"

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
He craves love, but his wife doesn't care;
Her sexcuses are full of hot air.
Like the tyres on his car,
He's prepared to go far,
So he's careful to carry a spare.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Dentalism: noun, obsolete.
Definition: "dentality." Neat.
What is that? "Dental quality."
Stop this frivolity!
Tell me its meaning tout de suite.

limerick_list.author: Errol Nimbly
limerick_list.text:
Biodiesel's big business.  It's choice!
I've brewed thousands of barrels.  Rejoice!
Well-oiled sales to civilians
Just pour in the millions
While I gas up my brand new Rolls Royce.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I know a young fellow named Bjorn
Who wishes he'd never been born,
'Cause his neighbor, named Sean,
Every morn greets the dawn
With arpeggios played on his horn.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Eucatastrophe turns every table
To assure a good end to a fable,
But the twist in the plot
Only twists what it's got:
There's no god swinging down from a gable.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Round a single bond, molecules twist,
But in some, forces tend to resist.
In butane-fueled warmers,
Four different conformers
Inseparably coexist.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"I've an African emerald to trade.
Will you offer some African jade?
This fine emerald is pure
As your jade is, I'm sure."
"That's exactly of what I'm afraid!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
To eat cheese is my present intent.
In my diet, it makes a big dent.
I choose French double creams;
Sweet and dreamlike each seems.
How much fat? At least 60%!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Munching Cheetos with Robert De Niro,
I remarked, "Do you know who's my hero?
The inventor of these
Puffy nothings of cheese
With nutritional values of zero!"

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle and Amergin
limerick_list.text:
Some roads in old Ireland are narrow:
Boreens around hillock and barrow.
One winds from Knockree
Down past Ballynashee
To the sea—not that far for a sparrow.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The fiery wife of a fifer
Set on fire what, in his words, she'd "die fer!"
She enfired his fave fife,
The prized pride of his life —
Said he'd knife her. He did; he's a lifer.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
When they're calling the roll, I say "Present!"
Some say "Yo!" but that isn't as pleasant.
Then there's Birdie (a schmuck)
Who responds with "Chuck-chuck!"
It turns out, though, he's some sort of pheasant.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
I'm so filled with desire for you;
Seems my heart is on fire for you.
When you leave me alone
I can't breathe on my own,
'Cause I only respire for you.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
My sister loves fancy apparel,
Though I'd be content in a barrel.
She opts for designers,
But I dress like miners
Or creatures from, say, Lewis Carroll.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
FDR might arrive around eight
For a round-the-world roller-skate date.
Wearing fishnets (that slut!)
He might breast-feed me, but
The dislikelihood's certainly great.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Common courtesy's offering your seat
On the bus; you should get to your feet
For the agéd and lame.
Do not look for acclaim,
But be gracious, and gently discreet.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Ammizabad: son of the guy
On whom David had learned to rely:
Benaiah, the chief
Of the troops whose belief
In their God was their strongest ally.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
We'd concluded the deal. As a closer,
We shook hands while your partner, a dozer,
Took a nap on my couch.
Is it true? Now that grouch
Is a controverter, foe—an opposer?

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
About half of my heart is auricular,
And the rest, I would guess, is ventricular.
Both are given to you;
Please don't cut them in two!
Ditch your knife and the stone that's coticular.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
From disaster is born a success!
The meringue fell apart, I confess;
And the strawberries and cream
Have continued this theme.
But it tastes like a dream — Eton mess!

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Leaving Rome, if your wheels tend to stray,
And what should take an hour takes a day,
And your collies are wobbling
It's due to the cobbling.
You're riding the Appian way!

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Crymodynia's "pain caused by cold".
As your frostbitten fingers unfold,
Then the pain becomes worse.
Just remember your nurse,
And wear mittens, the way you were told.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
For a Mormon, Bahai, or Confucian
There's no point to profane elocution.
You can sound just as frank
Saying blankety-blank;
It's their circumlocution solution.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
A small cameo brooch I'd adore,
Like the one that my Grandmother wore:
A silhouette face
Carved with beauty and grace—
It's a shame they're not worn any more.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
She is young; she's engaged, and she's proud—
Likes to show off her ring to a crowd.
Her fiance is fifty
But his bod is still nifty,
And his face?—apple-cheeked and smooth-browed.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"What's a style I might like to restore? A
Type of headgear," said Cora to Nora.
"Every day men wore hats.
They looked sexy, and that's
Why my dad always wore a fedora."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
New York Governor Spitzer's wide range
Of support, he discovered, would change
By reversal; sex bought
Led to Eliot caught.
(Politicians who fool us?  How strange.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
When we asked one world traveler's view
Of the best of the places he knew,
He looked dazed and then mumbled,
"They've all gotten jumbled;
It's clear that I don't have a clou."

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
For Him Magazine (FHM),
UK women know, isn't for them.
The British man's lifestyle
Contrasts with his wife's style:
There's rather more ogling. (Ahem.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The enemy troops' ambuscado
Had hit us just like a tornado.
Now we're ready to fight
And we'll catch them tonight
By surprise, with our great camisado.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
In Kentucky, one thoroughbred race
Called the Derby brings fame to this place:
Churchill Downs holds a crowd
Sentimental and loud—
At the Derby that's always the case.

limerick_list.author: FlippingMackerel
limerick_list.text:
They invited their friend to the "castle"
(They'd play kings and make him play the vassal).
"What a child's game!" shouted
The friend, and he pouted,
"When you're old, having fun is a hassle."

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
My ol' pa will be sleepin' till noon
Since we're lookin' to have a full moon.
He'll be makin' some noise
With my ma and the boys,
When they're out with the hounds huntin' coon.

limerick_list.author: mino and speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
In floodwaters, staying afloat
Calls for use of a watertight boat.
Or, if plucky (and lucky,
And sans rubber ducky):
Hold tight to a backstroking goat.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I often take parts in the staging
Of plays with young characters raging.
If I play such a part
I need not just my art,
But a fountain of youth (antiaging).

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Different metals united as one,
And used, say, in parts of a gun —
These alloys are stronger,
Corrode less, last longer
Than metals in "pure form" have done.

limerick_list.author: Buonarotti
limerick_list.text:
Exiled Clement, in Pontus enslaved,
Prayed for water the multitude craved.
Lo! A lamb touched the ground
Where a wellspring was found.
Many souls by this wonder were saved.

text: This is a test to see how well you are paying attention. This text is a series of limericks. At the end of the list of limericks, there will be a question. The question will be about one of the limericks. Please answer the question as concisely as possible.
